So basically, you want overpowered stackable instant health potions?  There's a reason they added hunger, you know.

"Overpowered stackable instant health potions", huh? Few things:

1. Food tends to be fairly overpowered in the first place, mostly due to saturation. Steak in particular is kinda crazy. With the saturation it gives, you can regenerate loads of health in no time.

2. They could make it so that it doesn't insta-heal much in the first place. Perhaps 4 points of health (2 hearts) would be the max. Perhaps food like steak wouldn't heal anything at all. Even in the above example I made sure it didn't heal a ridiculous amount.

3. They could always nerf heath restore via saturation.

4. They could always buff instant health potions. Four hearts after standing still for what feels like forever isn't the most optimal fighting strategy. There's no reason not to use the splash potions.

5. If it somehow IS as overpowered as you imply, they could always re-balance it.

If that's the only reason you haven't voted, I implore you to reconsider.

I have ab idea to marry the old and new food system: slow down healing from food, but still make it a requirement to eat, still stackable. if you want to heal quickly and (maybe almost) instantly you need to enchant your food a littlebit for instant benefit. however this is not stackable. this diversifies gameplay while keeping the new and recovering the old methods.

-food shouldn't heal instantly, rather slowly. the heart that food will refill will be brown. it still heal fast than max hunger heal

-saturation has been removed from the game in the latest snapshot, it should still be removed.

-crafted food will give you all the point with ingredent

-empty hunger meant can't sprint in normal or easy(wont lose heart). so at three point of hunger, you can still sprint(hard is the same, but you stop losing heart after half). only jump and sprint reduces hunger.

like apple heal the most but provide little hunger, steak provide the most hunger but heal the least

To answer the other person's questions,

/effect speed only works for run speed, on the ground

/tp won't help if you're just exploring or want to fill in a map

No, they are not going to remove crafting tables.

The reason they are adding these new blocks is because some crafting recipes, for whatever reason, cannot be added to the recipe book. Let's look at the cartography table. My guess is that it will be for mapmaking. Why? Because, in the crafting table, there's no way for a recipe to adequately express what is going on when you change a map from zoom level 2 to level 3, for example. It's just not designed for it. The cartography table will be.

And no, Wolvereigner, stonecutters are NOT going to be used for crafting stone blocks because stone block crafting recipes are simple and fit well with crafting table recipes.

TL;DR Mojang wants the recipe book to cover ALL recipes possible in the crafting table. All recipes that can't be described by the recipe book are being moved to a new block so that new players can better understand what's going on. THAT'S IT. If I'm wrong about this then you might have a point, but so far, none of your fears are justified.

I personally don't think this would help very much. To really understand what would help, you need to play the 1.9 combat a lot to really understand how the system works. My opinion on it changed a lot the more I played it. A great system would not be a system that tries to combine the two, but rather a new system that has elements of each of the systems, taking what good you can from both, but leaving exploits and unfair tactics from each.

Plus, your system would be hard to balance. But it might be possible.
Moved to Gameplay, despite being biome specific, it belongs here as it is not really about the biome itself, but a mechanic that is a gameplay issue for creative mode players.

Translation: 

Hello as the title says I will find it interesting to integrate a system of trading between players and a common currency as well as a basic value of all items/block... but it is still possible to put a different price than the value of Base of the object

I am sorry, but this would be an immensely unpopular change. People trying to complete large-scale building projects, for example, have a hard enough time carrying around all their building blocks, stairs, and slabs, food, tools, and other equipment all at once. But adding slowness on top of that? Not a good idea.

This would be realistic, but the inventory is already too small.  This would make the effective inventory space even smaller.

Think about it.  I don't believe the inventory has increased in size since the game was released.  But when the game was released, there were far fewer items available than there are today.  At this point, it can be very difficult to manage your inventory when building with a decently complex palette.  Your suggestion would make it so anyone who wants to be able to move at speed would have to treat their inventory as if they had even fewer spots than it already does.
You couldn't even carry one block of wool in real life, and that's about the lightest block I can think of, so I don't think this is a very good idea.
if you had 1 block of wool it would be 1,314 kilograms.Or over 2500 lbs, or 1 ton
